resource.chars:
It is proposed in the following pages to consider 
I The structure of the species of Salpa examined 
II The structure of Pyrosoma 
III The homology of structure of Salpa & Pyrosoma & of 
these with the ordinary ascidians.
IV The history of our knowledge of the Salpae 
I <u>The structure of Salpa <\u>
Before entering upon this question there is a point 
of some importance to be determined - as to the upper 
and lower surfaces, the anterior and posterior 
extremities of the Salpae - Observation will 
not decide this apparently simple matter, for as 
the writer has frequently seen, they swim in different 
with either end forward and with either side uppermost,
and the determinations of authors are most contradictory 
Throughout the present paper, that side on 
which the heart is placed will be considered as
 the dorsal side  - that on which the ganglion 
and auditory vesicle are placed, as the neutral side.
That extremity to which the mouth is turned 
will again be considered as the anterior extremity 
the opposite as the posterior. Such a view 
of the case, appears to be more harmonious with 
the determinations of corresponding parts in 
other animals  - than any other. In all <s>[text?]<\s>
the Invertebrata <s>[text?] kingdom <\s> the mouth end is considered 
as the anterior - the heart side as the <s>[text?<\s>
Dorsal side.
The two so-called species of Salpa examined 
were the S. democration of Forskahl, spinosa of Otto 
& the S. micronata of Forskahl, pyramidata of Quoy & 
Gaimard
